dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh my god. Are you kidding me? What, what's got you so worked up this time?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh my god. Are you kidding me? What, what's got you so worked up this time?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: This… this new fine in Kazakhstan! They’re just slapping fines on businesses for, like, exceeding a 15% markup on food, right off the bat.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: This... this new fine in Kazakhstan! They're just slapping fines on businesses for, like, exceeding a fifteen percent markup on food, right off the bat.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The main change concerned the replacement of the penalty for the first violation: instead of a warning, a fine is now provided. This means that for exceeding the established maximum trade markup of 15 percent on significant food products, entrepreneurs will not be warned, as before, but will be immediately fined,

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, yeah, that's exactly right. It's to ensure price stability, keep essential goods affordable for everyone. Seems pretty clear-cut to me.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, yeah, that's exactly right. It's to ensure price stability, keep essential goods affordable for everyone. Seems pretty clear-cut to me.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: According to the Ministry of Trade, the innovations are designed to ensure price stability for essential products and minimize the risks of unjustified price increases.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Clear-cut? It's draconian! Before, it was a warning. Now it's just, bam, fine! How is that fair to, like, small business owners?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Clear-cut? It's draconian! Before, it was a warning. Now it's just, bam, fine! How is that fair to, like, small business owners?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Previously, for the first violation, an entrepreneur received only a warning, and a fine of 10 to 300 MCI (39 320 - 1.1 million tenge in 2025) was applied only for a repeat violation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Because warnings weren't working, obviously. The Ministry said they initiated these changes to strengthen price controls. It's about preventing unjustified price hikes.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Because warnings weren't working, obviously. The Ministry said they initiated these changes to strengthen price controls. It's about preventing unjustified price hikes.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Ministry of Trade and Integration initiated the changes last year to strengthen price controls.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Unjustified? Uh, they literally say prices are going up because of 'seasonal factor' and 'storage costs' and 'utility tariffs'! That's not greedy markups, that's just… business!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Unjustified? Uh, they literally say prices are going up because of 'seasonal factor' and 'storage costs' and 'utility tariffs'! That's not greedy markups, that's just... business!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The increase in prices for the vegetable group is due to the seasonal factor and storage costs, taking into account the rise in utility tariffs,

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, but that's for some goods. The overall price index is, what, 0.3%? Sounds like it's working for the majority of products they're targeting.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, but that's for some goods. The overall price index is, what, zero point three percent? Sounds like it's working for the majority of products they're targeting.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: According to the Bureau of National Statistics, the price index for the significant food products as of April 1 was 0.3%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, 0.3%! Wow, big win for consumers! Meanwhile, they're still dishing out warnings alongside fines. The article says 1,119 warnings! I thought there were no more warnings for a first offense?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, zero point three percent! Wow, big win for consumers! Meanwhile, they're still dishing out warnings alongside fines. The article says eleven nineteen warnings! I thought there were no more warnings for a first offense?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As of March 20, 1189 decisions have already been recorded, including 70 fines in the amount of more than 5 million tenge, and 1119 warnings.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, um, maybe those warnings were for different violations, or before the 13th, or… I mean, the main thing is they're cracking down now. That's the point.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, um, maybe those warnings were for different violations, or before the thirteenth, or... I mean, the main thing is they're cracking down now. That's the point.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: The point is they're penalizing businesses without, like, addressing the actual problems. It's just shifting blame. A fine doesn't make cabbage cheaper if, uh, electricity costs more to store it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The point is they're penalizing businesses without, like, addressing the actual problems. It's just shifting blame. A fine doesn't make cabbage cheaper if, uh, electricity costs more to store it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It makes greedy businesses think twice about exploiting consumers. That 15% markup limit isn't some random number, it's there to protect people from price gouging on essentials.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It makes greedy businesses think twice about exploiting consumers. That fifteen percent markup limit isn't some random number, it's there to protect people from price gouging on essentials.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This means that for exceeding the established maximum trade markup of 15 percent on significant food products, entrepreneurs will not be warned, as before, but will be immediately fined,

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Price gouging? Or just trying to, you know, stay afloat? You can't just mandate affordability by fining people. It's, like, economic illiteracy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Price gouging? Or just trying to, you know, stay afloat? You can't just mandate affordability by fining people. It's, like, economic illiteracy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: No, it's economic responsibility. It's about protecting the population when prices for basic necessities start to get out of control. It's a necessary step.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, it's economic responsibility. It's about protecting the population when prices for basic necessities start to get out of control. It's a necessary step.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Necessary step to, uh, drive businesses out of business or create black markets. Mark my words.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Necessary step to, uh, drive businesses out of business or create black markets. Mark my words.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: You're being overly dramatic. They're just ensuring fair practice. It's a good move, Host_A. No, it's just a lazy, punitive one.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: You're being overly dramatic. They're just ensuring fair practice. It's a good move, Host_A. No, it's just a lazy, punitive one.
